lines.text: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur and the heedful slave Is wanderd forth, in care to seek me out By computation and mine hosts report. I could not speak with Dromio since at first I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes. How now sir! is your merry humour alterd As you love strokes, so jest with me again. You know no Centaur you received no gold Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner My house was at the Phoenix Wast thou mad, That thus so madly thou didst answer me
Enter DROMIO of Syracuse

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: What answer, sir when spake I such a word ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Even now, even here, not half an hour since.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: I did not see you since you sent me hence, Home to the Centaur, with the gold you gave me. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Villain, thou didst deny the golds receipt, And toldst me of a mistress and a dinner For which, I hope, thou feltst I was displeased.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: I am glad to see you in this merry vein: What means this jest I pray you, master, tell me. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth Thinkst thou I jest Hold, take thou that, and that.
Beating him

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Hold, sir, for Gods sake! now your jest is earnest: Upon what bargain do you give it me ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours. When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport, But creep in crannies when he hides his beams. If you will jest with me, know my aspect, And fashion your demeanor to my looks, Or I will beat this method in your sconce.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Sconce call you it so you would leave battering, I had rather have it a head: an you use these blows long, I must get a sconce for my head and ensconce it too or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders. But, I pray, sir why am I beaten ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Dost thou not know

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Shall I tell you why

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Ay, sir, and wherefore for they say every why hath a wherefore. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Why, first,for flouting me and then, wherefore For urging it the second time to me.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season, When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason Well, sir, I thank you. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Thank me, sir, for what

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Ill make you amends next, to give you nothing for something. But say, sir, is it dinnertime

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: No, sir I think the meat wants that I have. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: In good time, sir whats that

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Basting. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Well, sir, then twill be dry.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: If it be, sir, I pray you, eat none of it. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Your reason

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Well, sir, learn to jest in good time: theres a time for all things.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: I durst have denied that, before you were so choleric. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: By what rule, sir

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of father Time himself. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Lets hear it.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Theres no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: May he not do it by fine and recovery

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig and recover the lost hair of another man. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Why, but theres many a man hath more hair than wit.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: The plainer dealer, the sooner lost: yet he loseth it in a kind of jollity. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: For what reason

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: For two and sound ones too. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Nay, not sound, I pray you.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Sure ones, then. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Certain ones then. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Name them.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: The one, to save the money that he spends in trimming the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Marry, and did, sir namely, no time to recover hair lost by nature. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: But your reason was not substantial, why there is no time to recover.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald and therefore to the worlds end will have bald followers. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: I knew twould be a bald conclusion: But, soft! who wafts us yonder
Enter ADRIANA and LUCIANA

lines.speaker: adriana
lines.text: Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown: Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects I am not Adriana nor thy wife. The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweetsavord in thy taste, Unless I spake, or lookd, or touchd, or carved to thee. How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it, That thou art thus estranged from thyself Thyself I call it, being strange to me, That, undividable, incorporate, Am better than thy dear selfs better part. Ah, do not tear away thyself from me! For know, my love, as easy mayest thou fall A drop of water in the breaking gulf, And take unmingled that same drop again, Without addition or diminishing, As take from me thyself and not me too. How dearly would it touch me to the quick, Shouldst thou but hear I were licentious And that this body, consecrate to thee, By ruffian lust should be contaminate! Wouldst thou not spit at me and spurn at me And hurl the name of husband in my face And tear the staind skin off my harlotbrow And from my false hand cut the weddingring And break it with a deepdivorcing vow I know thou canst and therefore see thou do it. I am possessd with an adulterate blot My blood is mingled with the crime of lust: For if we too be one and thou play false, I do digest the poison of thy flesh, Being strumpeted by thy contagion. Keep then far league and truce with thy true bed I live unstaind, thou undishonoured. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Plead you to me, fair dame I know you not: In Ephesus I am but two hours old, As strange unto your town as to your talk Who, every word by all my wit being scannd, Want wit in all one word to understand.

lines.speaker: luciana
lines.text: Fie, brother! how the world is changed with you! When were you wont to use my sister thus She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: By Dromio

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: By me

lines.speaker: adriana
lines.text: By thee and this thou didst return from him, That he did buffet thee, and, in his blows, Denied my house for his, me for his wife. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman What is the course and drift of your compact

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: I, sir I never saw her till this time. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Villain, thou liest for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: I never spake with her in all my life. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: How can she thus then call us by our names, Unless it be by inspiration.

lines.speaker: adriana
lines.text: How ill agrees it with your gravity To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave, Abetting him to thwart me in my mood! Be it my wrong you are from me exempt, But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt. Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine: Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine, Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state, Makes me with thy strength to communicate: If aught possess thee from me, it is dross, Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss Who, all for want of pruning, with intrusion Infect thy sap and live on thy confusion. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: To me she speaks she moves me for her theme: What, was I married to her in my dream Or sleep I now and think I hear all this What error drives our eyes and ears amiss Until I know this sure uncertainty, Ill entertain the offerd fallacy.

lines.speaker: luciana
lines.text: Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: O, for my beads! I cross me for a sinner. This is the fairy land: O spite of spites! We talk with goblins, owls and sprites: If we obey them not, this will ensue, Theyll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.

lines.speaker: luciana
lines.text: Why pratest thou to thyself and answerst not Dromio, thou drone, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot!

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: I am transformed, master, am I not ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: I think thou art in mind, and so am I.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Thou hast thine own form.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: No, I am an ape.

lines.speaker: luciana
lines.text: If thou art changed to aught, tis to an ass.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Tis true she rides me and I long for grass. Tis so, I am an ass else it could never be But I should know her as well as she knows me.

lines.speaker: adriana
lines.text: Come, come, no longer will I be a fool, To put the finger in the eye and weep, Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn. Come, sir, to dinner. Dromio, keep the gate. Husband, Ill dine above with you today And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks. Sirrah, if any ask you for your master, Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter. Come, sister. Dromio, play the porter well. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell Sleeping or waking mad or welladvised Known unto these, and to myself disguised! Ill say as they say and persever so, And in this mist at all adventures go.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Master, shall I be porter at the gate

lines.speaker: adriana
lines.text: Ay and let none enter, lest I break your pate.

lines.speaker: luciana
lines.text: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late. ANTIPHOLUS
Exeunt
